title: Friday, 19th February, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:06 am
BE

Wait! It's alive! IT'S ALIVE!

BE

Welcome to Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily random crapshoot on whether the machines will do what we tell them.

BE

It's Friday, of course, and also the first day of London Fashion Week.

11:08 am
BE

That glorious time when all the Mayfair spivs get bounced back from their preferred hotel bars

BE

Because they're all packed full of miserable 14-year-old girls who look like skulls on pikes.

BE

And like all media ....

BE

BE

Nor, it seems, an FT story on the subject. I guess we're above talking shop. So here's the Guardian report instead: http://www.theguar...e-southwark-bridge

undefined

But I guess we should talk about markets.

11:17 am
BE

And hey, look, the FTSE opened flat, went up a bit head of the 10:40-ish auction print, then turned negative.

BE

Exactly as it always does.

BE

FTSE off 15 points at pixel, 5956

11:18 am
BE

And news is, well, light.

BE

(@Mo06: that's exactly what I said, wasn't it?)

BE

ROTR, I welcome your theories why we're down today. Your answers can include "Asia", "profit taking", "lack of catalysts" or any other cliche.

11:21 am
BE

(@Mo06: yup, by print I meant the expiry fix.)

BE

(@TheLeggie: be nice.)

BE

In the meantime, we'll rattle through what little news there is.

11:22 am
undefined
BE

ONS. Retail sales.

BE

January 5% yoy or 2.3% mom

11:24 am
BE

Consensus was 3.4% and 0.7%, so massive beat.

BE

Which for me raises the question why people were buying everything but train sets ....

Hornby PLC (HRN:LSE): Last: 36.18, up 0.68 (+1.92%), High: 37.00, Low: 37.00, Volume: 19.66k
11:24 am
BE

... but others have more broad concerns.

BE

Here's Berenberg.

BE

If consumption is the backbone of the UK economy, then retail spending is the canary in the coalmine. Retail sales volumes excluding auto fuel grew for a 33rd consecutive month yoy in January, increasing 5.0% versus expectations of 3.4% and up significantly on the December slowdown of 1.8%. The January rebound from the weather affected December was more than three times larger than expected, indicating a pick-up in domestic demand. On a monthly basis sales increased by 2.3%, the strongest mom growth rate since December 2013. Compared on a 3m/3m basis, volumes increased by 1.1%; 0.2 ppt above the average 3m/3m growth rate of 0.9% in 2015. There were broad improvements across all categories of spending indicating that the growing appetites of UK consumers have yet to be impacted by the January rout in financial markets or the broad decline in market sentiment on the UK outlook.

A strong week for UK data should help ease market worries: With improvements in both inflation and labour market data earlier this week, this big upside surprise supports our call that UK fundamentals are strong despite heightened risks. Last week we brought down our Q1 and Q2 growth calls by 0.1pp to 0.4% qoq due the market selloff and growing Brexit risk. But 80% of the UK economy is domestic-consumption driven services. Retail sales therefore, are a good proxy for services demand and strong retail data typically points to healthy GDP growth. If this trend persists, it would indicate some upside risk to our near-term GDP calls.

11:27 am
BE

And Barclays.

BE

· All categories reported positive growth on the month. The significant
upside surprise was led by non-food store retailing, contributing 1.5pp,
and making up for its detraction in December; it rose 3.6% m/m, its
largest rise since December 2013. Food store retailing rose by 1.1% m/m
(+0.4pp contrib.) while automotive fuel rose by 2.5% m/m (+0.3pp
contrib.). Non-store retailing remains more muted (+0.1pp contrib., 1.4%
m/m).

· Today’s significant upside surprise more than cancels out December’s
downside surprise, leaving the Q1 16 carry-over at 1.8% q/q after 1.1%
q/q in Q4 15. This would result in a 0.13pp positive contribution to Q1
16 services output if realised. Today’s print supports our baseline
scenario that private consumption growth should print at 0.5% q/q in Q1
16 (down 0.1pp from Q4 15; Figure 5). Further out, in light of
decelerating nominal wage growth and us expecting inflation to pick up
gradually in 2016 (we forecast 0.8%), as well as the Government’s
impending fiscal consolidation, these factors are all likely to weigh on
households’ spending habits, eating further into consumption. As such, we
see it easing to 0.4%/0.3% q/q by mid-2016.

BE

(@chad_john: when you're an analyst, being wrong is the risk. The direction of wrongness is immaterial.)

11:28 am
BE

We also have Barclays on the preliminary Q4 GDP

BE

Which is going to be a big lump of grey you have the option of reading, or not.

BE

The services component of the December 2015 Turnover and Orders in
Production and Services Industries (TOPSI) release printed 1.5% m/m,
resulting in a 1.9% q/q decline for Q4 15 (in non-seasonally adjusted
nominal terms) after 2.8% q/q growth in Q3 15. We estimate this to
correspond to a 3.0% q/q decline (in seasonally adjusted real terms;
based on our implied Q4 15 GDP deflator estimate) after a 0.9% q/q
decline in Q3 15.

We revise down our Q4 15 GDP forecast 0.1pp to 0.4% q/q in light of this
weak print, as well weakness in industrial production and construction
output (released 10 February and 12 February, respectively). We therefore
expect the ONS to revise down its estimate of Q4 15 GDP growth by 0.1pp
on the second release (25 February 2016) from a print of 0.5% q/q in the
preliminary release.

This underscores our bottom-of-consensus economic forecasts and more
cautious macro view. Indeed, it appears the magnitude of the slowdown was
more amplified than even we had anticipated, with downward revisions
already having been made to Q2 15 and Q3 15 growth (0.2pp and 0.1pp,
respectively). This supports our view that economic activity is to ease
0.3pp to 1.9% in 2016, followed by 1.6% in 2017.

11:30 am
BE

The details

The preliminary estimate of Q4 15 GDP growth printed at 0.48% q/q (see UK
Q4 15 Preliminary GDP: Slow, slow, slow she goes, 28 January 2016). This
was driven primarily by Services (+0.52pp contrib., 0.66% q/q), with
Industrial Production and Construction detracting (-0.03pp contrib.,
-0.24% q/q and -0.01pp, -0.13% q/q respectively).

The preliminary estimate of GDP, however, is based on information
available by mid-January, with forecasts used for any data unavailable at
the time of the release. Thus, the December prints for industrial
production and construction output were not readily available at the
preliminary GDP estimate’s release. As we highlighted in UK Outlook: A
summit that could decide the UK-EU future, it transpires that the Q4
growth for industrial production and construction output printed
weaker-than-expected; because both sectors combined make up 20% of the UK
economy, this resulted in a 0.06pp downside risk to the preliminary
headline GDP growth estimate.

undefined
BE

@Nichoman, I have no qualms in admitting I didn't understand Indivior's gain yesterday.

11:31 am
BE

Headline EPS beat on a lower tax rate.

BE

Below that, it was in line. 2016 guidance was okay, but it was always going to be as April is the key date to find out whether they can keep the franchise running without patent protection.

BE

Sorry to shout. Hi, hello, welcome.

11:34 am
BE

It's a lazy habit to blame this kind of thing on half term, and a lack of bodies around, but I'm not sure that's entirely untrue either.

BE

Here's Deutsche Bank.

BE

We believe today’s out- performance
was simply because the company did not disappoint coupled with upbeat
commentary around the ongoing litigation and an entry price which, in our
view, was already pricing in a worst case litigation outcome. Our forecasts are
broadly unchanged after results and are in-line with unchanged 2016 guidance.
We maintain our Buy and 240p for longer term pipeline value.

11:35 am
BE

Miinimal changes to top line; Improvement to bottom line on lower tax rate
We make minimal changes to our Indivior forecasts after a straightforward set
of results. Top line is unchanged but we slightly increase EPS with higher
financial expenses in the near term offset by an improvement in tax rate across
all years (down to 25% from 27%). Our 2016 revenue forecasts of $956m are
at the lower end of guidance ($945-975m) but ahead of pre-results consensus
of $923m. On net income, our 2016 forecasts of $172m are broadly in line with
guidance ($155-180m) and consensus $168m. Models overleaf.
Other key takeaways from the quarter
Key takeaways include: 1) Management were confident there would be a court
ruling early 2Q and there would not be an at-risk generic launch. It was
highlighted no ANDAs have yet been approved, damages from an at-risk
launch can be significant and there are further trials on different patents
scheduled for later in the year. We assume first generic launches from late-17;
2) Settlement discussions continue and, in our view, there was a clear desire
from management to remove this significant overhang. Whilst we still believe
a settlement is unlikely from a practical perspective given the market
complexities, any settlement would be a significant positive; 3) Phase III data
for monthly buprenorphine is expected from late 3Q and will be detailed at an
R&D day in 4Q; 4) Management sees scope to further improve the tax rate
from 2016’s expected 25% as newer products launch.
Catalysts, Valuation and Risks: Buy, PT 240p
Key catalysts include: 1) A court ruling on the litigation in April; 2) Critical Ph III
data for monthly buprenorphine from late 3Q which we expect to be positive.
Our 240p TP is set at a c.15% discount to our 280p DCF valuation (10% WACC,
beta 1.3, ERP 5.5%, RFR 4%, TGR 0%) given the significant litigation overhang.
Risks include: (1) Loss of litigation or launch of generics before our assumed
late-17; (2) Pipeline failure; (3) Issuance of a fine as a result of anti-trust
investigation; (4) Greater than expected share loss/pricing pressure.

undefined
BE

Segro? Sure. Nothing's too dull for this Friday.

11:37 am
SEGRO PLC (SGRO:LSE): Last: 432.11, up 0.4116 (+0.10%), High: 437.30, Low: 429.20, Volume: 614.72k
BE

4% beat against consensus.

BE

Stifel can summarise.

11:38 am
BE

Segro's results showed a strong performance in 2015 with NAV and earnings c.4% ahead of our expectations.
A lack of supply in industrial property and good occupier demand is leading to improving rental growth in the
UK, and in Europe the market is beginning to stabilise. The shares have been resilient in turbulent equity
markets, and we expect this to remain the case given the strength of the underlying industrial property market,
albeit one where yield compression is likely to now slow. We retain our Buy rating

BE

Valuation & rating. Segro shares have been resilient during a turbulent start
to the year for the real estate sector, up 1%, outperforming the sector by 13%.
Income-focused companies and those with exposure to industrial/distribution
property have performed well, and we expect Segro to continue to benefit from
this improved sentiment given the late-cycle growth characteristics of the asset
class and the structural demand for logistics space driven by changing
consumer behaviour.
NAV 463p, up 21% over the year, ahead of our forecast of 445p, driven by
11.1% capital growth in the like-for-like investment portfolio. The UK portfolio
valuation was up 13.1%, outperforming Europe which was up 7.9%. Yield
compression was a significant driver of capital growth, though rental growth
has risen compared to the year before and is becoming a more important
component of valuation improvements. In the UK, the average yield fell 30bps
and rental growth was 4.4%. In Europe, yields fell 100bps and rental values
fell 0.9%. Much of the fall in rental values was in Central Europe in the first
half, with the second half stable, and management commented that there are
pressures growing on rental values across Europe.
EPS 18.4p, up 7% and ahead of our forecast of 17.8p, as the company
returned to earnings growth following the completion of its restructuring
programme in 2014. The rise in earnings was driven by a 4.2% increase in net
rental income (UK +5.2%, Europe +1.2%) and a fall in vacancy to a record low
of 4.8% (down from 6.3%). We believe the fall in vacancy demonstrates the
strong occupier demand for industrial assets. DPS 15.6p, up 3.3%, close to
our forecast of 15.5p.
Office disposals. Post year-end, Segro disposed of its offices at Bath Road
for £325m. Though this reduces rental income, we believe the company can
recoup this with deployment of the capital into its development programme and
acquisitions. We interpret the increase in the dividend ahead of expectations
as a signal as to management's confidence in future earnings growth.
Developments. In strong occupier markets the company has been able to
commence more speculative developments, with a pipeline capable of
delivering £109m of new rental income, which is equivalent to 38% of the
company's current income stream.

BE

And ..... SocGen, I guess.

11:40 am
BE

Main surprises FY 15 results beat consensus on all metrics. NAV at 463p is 3% above
consensus and 2% above SGe. EPS up 7% yoy at 18.4p is 2% above consensus but 1%
below SGe. DPS up 3% at 15.6p is 1% above SGe/cons 15.5p. Better NAV (+21% yoy, +
11% H2) was driven by 70bp yield compression over the year to 6.0% (true equivalent
yield), essentially thanks to 110bp yield compression in Continental Europe to 6.8%, while
the UK saw a 50bp yield shift to 5.8%. Net rental income (LFL) is up 4.2% yoy (+5.2% UK,
+1.2% CE), in line with the first half, benefitting from a 1.5% reduction in vacancy down to
4.8%. Adj. profit after tax at £137m is £1m above our estimate, with £9m lower net rental
income (£233m) compensated by £5m higher management fees (£17m) and £3m lower
financial costs (£81m). LTV improved from 41% end-June to 34% end-Dec. (SGe 35%).

BE

Potential impact on SG & market forecast Restructuring started in 2012 is now
completed. From here we expect SGRO to capitalise on its profitable development activity
and on further yield compression in Europe. The higher than expected dividend reflects
management’s confidence in its ability to offset the loss of income (1.2p/s) from ‘Bath road’
disposals. Furthermore “a quarter of the vacancy is in newly completed developments
which we expect to lease in the near future". All of these factors should drive further growth
in NAV while EPS should remain mostly stable, in our view.
Potential impact on share price/recommendation The stock should outperform its peers
today. However a 3.8% dividend yield indicates to us that most of the good news is already
priced-in. Our TP of 420p reflects a 2% premium to our fair value of 416p (10y DCF (6.9%
WACC, 2% perp. growth), GS norm. dividend model (392p), 10y DDM (359p)).

undefined
11:42 am
BE

(@Guidinghand: Indivior's own history of trying to game the patent expiries with blister packs and films has hardly been edifying to watch either.)

BE

@TheLeggie: nope, nothing to add on what was written yesterday. Consolidation doesn't make a huge amount of sense and the maths of PE look very stretched -- though clearly it's routine for PE to investigate every company whose market cap is so deeply sub the theoretical value of its 90%-freehold property portfolio.)

BE

So what else do we have? ITV, maybe?

11:47 am
BE

Ian Whittaker at Liberum has been talking to the media buyers.

BE

We spoke with a UK media buyer on the TV market and ITV in particular. Their view was that both continue to hold up very well and that ITV should have another good year in 2016. Importantly, it was stated that the much reported “underperformance” of ITV in Q1 was more of a mechanical factor due to ITV’s expected strong Q2/Q4 performance and ITV is on track to outperform the market in 2016. Reiterate as top pick in media. We have 5% ITV advertising growth for FY16E and feel comfortable with this.

ITV PLC (ITV:LSE): Last: 253.60, up 4 (+1.60%), High: 253.90, Low: 249.10, Volume: 2.13m
11:48 am
BE

The "underperformance" referred to there was via Deutsche Bank, as in this: http://www.ft.com/...-c5e23ef99c77.html

BE

The feedback was that ITV has started the year in a good position, up +7% yoy in January. On a like for like basis, this equates to+4%-5% with the rest of the gain coming from the first time inclusion of Video on Demand in the ITV TV advertising growth numbers (the media buyer’s view was that the additional effect was not as much as the 3% mentioned in other brokers’ recent commentary).

For the FY, their view is that the UK TV market will be up 5%-6%, with ITV ahead 7%-8%, implying c. 5% for ITV advertising growth for FY16 on an underlying basis, in line with our forecasts. We have 5% ITV advertising growth for FY16E so are comfortable with our forecasts.

BE

On the debate around TV’s resilience and that of ITV, the feedback was positive: TV – and ITV – were still seen to deliver at an attractive price and there was certainly no feeling that advertisers are shifting their money aggressively out of TV. It was also pointed out that there were significant differences between the UK and US TV markets. On audiences, ITV1 seems to be holding up well in most categories although there is some softness in 16-34 with Sky picking up some share.

11:49 am
BE

The media buyer made reference to some of the recent commentary that ITV is underperforming the market in Q1 (Channel 4 was up an estimated 11% in January). In their view, this was entirely expected given ITV’s FY schedule – because ITV (a) gains share in Q4 as advertisers push money into it ahead of Christmas and (b) should gain share in Q2 and possibly Q3 because it has the Euro 2016 football matches, media buyers need to shift money to other channels in other quarters to meet their FY commitments. It was also stated that Channel 4 is cheap at this time of the year relative to other quarters, again making sense for media buyers to put their money into this channel at such an early stage. The fact that ITV is actually up mid-single digits in January on an underlying basis despite this is therefore a positive sign.

BE

Which reminds me ......

BE

On our occasional theme of click fraud.

11:51 am
BE

Interesting op-ed in yesterday's Campaign.

BE

https://twitter.com/and_partnership/status/700251076113645568

BE

Involving quite immoderate language.

11:52 am
BE

Now, clearly, it's a promotion for Adloox, which is one of several hundred companies trying to become the S&P or the Fitch of online advertising verification.

BE

But "The&Partnership" is also backed by WPP.

BE

If this is the kind of tone the ad industry's adopting now, where does it leave click farms?

11:54 am
BE

Looking at you here, Axel Springer.

undefined
BE

Someone, earlier, asked about GKP.

11:55 am
Gulf Keystone Petroleum Ltd (GKP:LSE): Last: 15.80, up 0.3 (+1.94%), High: 17.75, Low: 15.50, Volume: 3.65m
BE

And the dripfeed of cash from the KRG that continues to keep them alive.

BE

The question, I guess, is why?

11:57 am
BE

Cantor says ............

BE

Our View: GKP has reported that the company has received a US$15m gross (US$12m net) payment from the Kurdish Regional Government (KRG) for January sales. This follows regular payments in 4Q/2015, but is the first of 2016. We also note that the KRG is now addressing the arrears it has built up to domestic operators, and whilst today’s announcement is only a small payment in this respect to GKP, it signals the government’s intent this year. We reiterate our BUY recommendation and our TP of 48p.

· A pattern is emerging – Further to the KRG's Ministry of Natural Resources ("MNR") press release of 1 February 2016, this payment is being made on the basis of the company's monthly contractual revenue entitlement under the Shaikan PSC for exports in January 2016 of US$5.8m gross. In addition to the monthly entitlement, a payment of US$9.2m gross is being made towards the recovery of the arrears.

· Higher payments this year will be key – The KRG has been vocal in announcing that it intends to address its arrears in 2016 by increasing payments to operators (GKP’s receivable is currently over US$300m). Nevertheless, following protracted civil and political issues in Iraq, the semi-autonomous region finds itself in fiscal deficit, and therefore will be under pressure if it looks to increase payments to operators.
· Trades at a significant discount to Risked NAV – We reiterate our TP of 48p/share, citing material upside potential in 2016 if Kurdistan-specific issues improve. Once a regular payment cycle is established (which we would identify as six consecutive months), and GKP is receiving adequate cash flows, we believe the shares will re-rate to a more applicable price to the fundamental value of the company.

BE

So, GKP's effectively being subsidised on a survival dripfeed to produce.

11:59 am
BE

Oh, and by the way ....

BE

https://twitter.com/iraqoilreport/status/700467580000014336

BE

(@dorsetcontrarian: I made the editorial judgement that, given the volume of intelligent comment on Brexit elsewhere on FT.com, my contributions could only dilute the overall quality.)

12:00 pm
undefined
BE

So we've made it to midday again.

BE

In spite of having no news whatsoever.

12:02 pm
BE

Thanks, ROTR, both today and this week.

BE

It's been patchy, for myriad unconnected reasons, so thanks for your patience.

BE

We -- as in we, not just the royal we -- will be back next week.

12:03 pm
BE

Until then, have a good one.
